body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West at 79th Street. ''Capturing Time: The New York Times Capsule'' includes some of the nearly 50 design proposals received in a New York Times Magazine competition to create a time capsule for preserving artifacts from today for the next 1,000 years. title: SPARE TIMES

body: For years, John Jay High School, on Seventh Avenue near Fourth Street, has been troubled, ranking high among the city's schools in assaults and robberies and low in test scores and graduation rates. John Jay is situated in the prosperous heart of Park Slope, but many parents there never dreamed of sending their children to the school. The local
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN; School Board May Try to Take Over Troubled John Jay

body: Baking Benefits the Theater And the Handicapped Four years ago, Rick Curry, a Jesuit brother who founded and directs the New York-based National Theater Workshop of the Handicapped, started turning his bread-baking hobby into a moneymaker for the organization by making breads on order and selling them to benefit the workshop. Brother Curry, who is
title: FOOD STUFF

body: SO you thought you'd seen the last of turkey for a while, right? Sorry. BOERUM HILL FOOD COMPANY in Brooklyn serves a turkey club sandwich ($6.50) that is so good it may make people forget that turkey is only for holidays. Turkey breast and thick strips of bacon are served on excellent hallah, moistened with tangy cranberry sauce and sweet-potato
title: TO GO; Sandwiches That Travel

body: BADOO'S INTERNATIONAL RESTAURANT ++ (718) 345-7654; 5422 Church Avenue, at East 55th Street, Flatbush; $; no smoking; cash only. This tiny storefront serves wonderful jerk chicken, the barbecued dish of Jamaica. Beware of the sauce. It is spiked with Scotch bonnet peppers, which are fiery. The menu changes daily, but most days you can get pepper
title: GOOD EATING; Small Is Beautiful In Brooklyn

body: I COULD tell right away that a place called Saul was serious and ambitious. The clue was the missing '' 's.'' Casual neighborhood places are called Fred's or Jerry's or Mergatroid's. But stir a little ambition into a restaurant's pot and it eliminates the Anglophone possessive faster than Eddie Fisher dropped Debbie Reynolds. These restaurants are
title: $25 AND UNDER; In Brooklyn, a Neighborhood Spot With Ambition

body: Even Manhattan partisans are aware of the extraordinary selection of restaurants in Brooklyn and Queens. Each of these 12 restaurants presents a different cuisine, and but for the length of this column, the list could have gone on and on. title: EATING OUT; Beyond Manhattan

body: ''WHAT'S astounding to people is my Silver Queen corn,'' Barbara Schwartz said, pointing to a bumper crop -- 10 teeny ears -- growing 16 stories up on the terrace of her Park Avenue penthouse. So exotic is the spectacle of espaliered apples, wild strawberries, blueberries, sweet potatoes, purple basil, runner beans, garlic and cabbages thriving in
title: Old MacDonald Had a Penthouse

body: BEING a calm, poker-face kind of guy, I rarely go into an eyes-rolling-into-the-back-of-the-head swoon, but that was my reaction on my first bite of the fabulous heirloom tomato salad at the VICTORY KITCHEN . The salad ($3.50) is a testament to the simple but much-abused formula of allowing fine ingredients to speak for themselves. It was not only
title: TO GO; The Chef's Touch in Every Box

body: George Norton, 52, a Mohawk Indian and an ironworker, has seen his neighborhood change over the years from an urban center for Mohawks, with their own bars and grocery stores selling traditional foodstuffs, to a place where an American Indian presence is barely visible. Mohawk ironworkers and their families were drawn to Boerum Hill because it was
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL -- THROUGH THE EYES OF; Remembering Mohawk Ironworkers' Urban Haven

body: A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth was fatally shot and a bystander was seriously wounded early yesterday after an argument at a high school graduation party in a backyard in East New York, the police said. The party was at a two-story apartment building at 781 Belmont Avenue in Brooklyn, the police said. The shots sent the dozens of partygoers running,
title: A Teen-Ager Is Fatally Shot And Another Is Hurt at a Party

body: Finally there were crowds at Treasures Thrift Emporium on Fourth Street near Seventh Avenue, but only because of the liquidation sale. Paperbacks went for pennies and a model of a giant aspirin tablet sold for a song as the thrift store marked its first anniversary last Sunday by going out of business. Opened last June by the South Brooklyn Local
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE; Job-Training Project Becomes Part of Unemployment List

body: The instructions for the English test taken this year by all New York fourth graders included ''check your work.'' But that is a lesson that has apparently gone unlearned not just among the two-thirds of the city's fourth graders who failed the test but also at the Department of Transportation, at least when it comes to the corner of Boerum Place
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE/COBBLE HILL; It's Not Just Kids Who Flunk Spelling

body: At the Victory, a two-month-old cafe and takeout spot in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, customers who sidle up to the counter are served a dose of tongue-in-cheek theatrics with their old-time drinks. Servers in lab coats measure out fruity homemade soda syrups in glass beakers, and mix them with carbonated water spritzed from silver-spouted blue bottles
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Old-Fashioned but Not Jerky: Lab-Coated Soda Spritzers

body: Surrounded by the government buildings and parking lots of downtown Brooklyn is a verdant block where window boxes trail asparagus fern, and slender stalks of bamboo grow from barrels topped by a flowering bog rosemary. The block, a stretch of State Street between Bond and Hoyt Streets in Boerum Hill, is so strikingly lush, it was designated the
title: Plant Thieves Plague a Block In Brooklyn; Neighbors Irate but Baffled By Well-Dressed Suspects

body: Brooklyn Bridge may not be falling down, but the magazine can no longer afford to be published monthly, its owner and editor in chief, Melissa Ennen, said last week. Three of the five news staff members were laid off on April 30, and the magazine will now be put together by freelance editors and writers and published every other month, Ms. Ennen
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; Magazine Revises Its Span

body: A police sergeant who was trying to issue a summons to a teen-ager for drinking on a downtown Brooklyn street corner yesterday shot him three times after the youth pointed a gun at the sergeant during a struggle, the authorities said. The unidentified youth, who the police said was about 16, was in critical but stable condition with wounds to the
title: Police Shoot Teen-Ager They Say Pointed Gun

body: FROM the heights of Manhattan's luxury towers to the wood-framed and aluminum-sided homes of its more proletarian neighborhoods, New York City's residential real estate market saw prices continue to rise last year -- riding the crest of the nation's record-breaking housing expansion and the region's ongoing rebound from the moribund days of the
title: In All 5 Boroughs, A Robust Market

body: Foundation, a contemporary furniture spot amid a sea of antiques shops, is set to open next week. Jayme Sklar, a Red Hook resident and Fashion Institute of Technology graduate, is opening the shop at 329 Atlantic Avenue (between Smith and Hoyt Streets) in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. She estimates that there are about 30 antiques shops in the vicinity.
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; A Contemporary Island In a Sea of Antiques

body: In the latest annoyance for Brooklyn subway riders, the two busiest lines between lower Manhattan and Brooklyn's largest subway hub -- the station at Atlantic and Flatbush Avenues -- were shut down for 49 minutes during the morning rush yesterday after snow shorted out an electrical cable. Not all the news for Brooklyn commuters was bad yesterday.
title: Subway Cable Fails, Closing a Brooklyn Hub

body: Subway riders in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn yesterday found a patchwork of shuttle trains and buses to help them bypass the Bergen Street station of the F and G lines, whose control panel was ravaged by fire Thursday night. Riders on the G train, a little-used local line that makes 26 stops, meandering from Jamaica, Queens, to Smith
title: After Fire, Delays on Subway Stir Grumbling Among Riders

body: A control room fire on the F and G subway lines in Brooklyn on Thursday night destroyed critical switching equipment, forcing transportation officials to close five stations and disrupt service yesterday for more than 150,000 passengers in several Brooklyn neighborhoods. Officials of New York City Transit said last night that most service would be
title: After Station Fire, Subway Lines Face Months of Turmoil

body: For six decades, an undeveloped swath of a little more than two blocks has divided downtown and brownstone Brooklyn. Now a community task force wants to see that space filled with buildings that would create an architectural buffer zone between the two areas. The task force, whose members were appointed by Borough President Howard Golden, envisions
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; A Plan to Turn Some Parking Lots Into Parks, and More

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Selling a Bit of Everything With a Lot of Family Help

body: When the Board of Education divvied up the $10.9 billion it plans to spend on construction, repair and renovation in the next five years, it allotted some districts hundreds of millions of dollars to build schools. District 15 was not among them. But last week, local school board members laid the groundwork for a campaign they hope will reverse
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WESTERN BROOKLYN; District Says School Construction Numbers Don't Add Up

body: Times Square Jr. Q. Over the doors at the post office at 542 Atlantic Avenue (near Third Avenue) in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, it says Times Plaza Station. Why? A. In Manhattan, soon after The New York Times moved to Longacre Square in 1905, the square's name was changed to Times Square. Brooklyn, too, had a Times Square of sorts, though for only about
title: F.Y.I.
